always at your parties Frasier and
yellowtail carpaccio has the world gone
mad?" "oh by the way you are welcome" "Oh.... for what?" "for turning you on to the best

thing you will ever eat: barbecue pudding
chips!" "Thanks" [TV clips end] Hey what's up guys? Welcome

back to "Binging with Babish" where this
week at long last we are exploring the

foods from "Frasier," actor John Mahoney
passed away last weekend it seemed a

fitting tribute to take a look at some
of the fancy FETs from the storied

sitcom. Unfortunately, none of these can
be found in the official "Cafe Nervosa

Connoisseur's Cookbook" so we're gonna
have to improvise

first up the Cornish game hens with
Frasier's signature pomegranate-honey

sauce. Let's start by butterflying the
hens, removing their backbones, and then

cutting them in half reserving the
backbones for later. We're gonna need
them to make the sauce. Lightly season the underside of the hens with kosher

salt, flip, and combine three or four
tablespoons of kosher salt with maybe a

teaspoon of baking powder this is going
to lower the temperature at which the my
maillard reaction occurs giving us browner skin it's also going to desiccate the

skin as we season the other side of the
hens with the salt and baking powder and

refrigerate uncovered for a bare minimum
of four hours and up to over night.

While the birds are doing their thing
it's time to make some Cornish game hen

stock out of the spines. A couple
aromatics like a carrot, half an onion, a

stalk of celery. Some fresh herbs like a
few sprigs of thyme, a few sprigs of

rosemary, a few sprigs of fresh parsley, a
clove of garlic, we've talked about stock

plenty of times on the show... So just add
whatever you got in the fridge it's
gonna come out good. We cut up the spines into manageable pieces and browned them

before adding all additional aromatics.
Covering with cold water and bringing to

a bare simmer letting cook for a solid
two or three hours until a very

flavorful stock forms. This is going to
be one of the three ingredients that

goes in our pomegranate-honey sauce
before we do that however our guests

have arrived and it's time to get
carpaccio ready. I am thinly slicing some

scallions, radishes, jalapenos, and blood
oranges just because they look pretty

can't find blood oranges you can use any
kind of citrus: grapefruit, regular

oranges, whatever you want.
Let's also slice a lemon in half because

we're gonna make a vinaigrette out of
another blood orange, some olive oil,

probably a solid 1/2 cup of olive oil:
50/50 blood orange to olive oil. Some

chives we want to get a little oniony
flavor in there- you could also use a

shallot-a little squeeze of lemon, and
we're gonna beat this together with a

whisk or a fork until a thick emulsion
forms. You could use this on any salad
but it's gonna be great in our carpaccio. Speaking of which is

time for the carpaccio part of our
carpaccio which Niles and Daphne's

dinner guests exclaims is yellowtail.
Make sure you are using sushi-grade

yellowtail because we are eating this
raw we're just going to arrange and

layer everything decoratively on a plate
so any given bites will give you the

opportunity to have a little bit of each
element and we're going to generously

drizzle everything with our blood orange
vinaigrette.

It's a lovely and delicious appetizer if
you're looking to take your first foray

into raw fish and if you use a fork very
strategically you can take a bite

without your guests ever knowing. After
all, we always want to taste our food

before serving it. Now it's time to make
our signature pomegranate-honey sauce

this is simply going to be a mixture of
maybe two parts Cornish game hen stock

to one part pomegranate juice, a drizzle
of honey whisked together and let simmer

until thick and syrupy. You can set this
aside and warm it up when we're ready to

serve. For now we got to make our wild
rice stuffing combine a cup of uncooked

wild rice with two to two and a quarter
cups of Cornish game hen stock and cook

via your favorite method. Then we're
going to turn that wild rice into 'hushwee'

a Lebanese wild rice and lamb
stuffing that I think would probably go

best with something like a pomegranate
sauce. So we are sweating one small onion

and a couple cloves of minced garlic for
a few minutes or until translucent and

then browning maybe a pound of ground
lamb. Make sure that it's mostly cooked

through and you got some nice crispy
brown bits before combining the two and

adding the cooked wild rice and now it's
time to spice this mixture that's what's

going to separate this from every other
wild rice stuffing you've ever had. We're

adding a sprinkle of cinnamon, a sprinkle
of ground allspice, a sprinkle of cardamom

-a healthy sprinkle of cardamom- a little
kosher salt, and then a good handful of

currants, regular raisins or I'm going to
use golden raisins for a little bit of a
color difference, a nice squeeze of lemon from the lemon

that we saved from our carpaccio- you
didn't throw that away right? and a few

twists of freshly ground pepper. Now it's
time to deal with our hens spray down

with nonstick spray and this great
little trick comes from America's Test

Kitchen pre-heat your oven to 500
degrees Fahrenheit with an aluminum

sheet pan inside it then place the birds
skin side down on the sheet pan this is

gonna get them crisping up bake for 10
minutes flip and place under the broiler

for 5 to 8 minutes or until the hens
register 160 degrees Fahrenheit in the

breast and they're nice and crispy like
this. Now finally it's time to play top

the rice with a little bit of freshly
chopped parsley and a little bit of

freshly chopped mint and some pine nuts
that we've quickly toasted in olive oil.

Then it's time to Park some poultry
right next to our rice and drizzle a

pool of sauce around the outside of the
bird now legend has it that I attempted

this episode a year and a half ago and
trashed it because my guests and I got a

little bit too drunk at dinner and I
didn't change the recipe one bit since

then because it really is fabulous and
as a lovely romantic dinner for this
